intro: Helmia daemona, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a striking plant native to the mountainous regions of South America. It is a member of the Polemoniaceae family and is characterized by its vibrant purple and red flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its foliage consists of narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a fine, silvery pubescence. Helmia daemona is notable for its unique appearance and is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens.
